listitem.para: Access paths - strategies used to access data within table
Indexes - good for when accessing small amounts of data out of much larger data set
Full table scans - good for small tables and unrestricted row access
Any row can be *functionally* accessed with either method
Use execution plans to help use the appropriate technique

section.title: Full Table Scan: Unconstrained Access
section.para: Request N rows of data from a table with no defined order

figure.title: JPA Query
figure.programlisting: "select m from Movie m", limit=1000

figure.title: Generated SQL
figure.programlisting: select * from ( select movie0_.ID as ID1_2_, movie0_.DIRECTOR_ID as DIRECTOR7_2_, movie0_.MINUTES as MINUTES2_2_, movie0_.PLOT as PLOT3_2_, movie0_.RATING as RATING4_2_, movie0_.RELEASE_DATE as RELEASE5_2_, movie0_.TITLE as TITLE6_2_ from JPATUNE_MOVIE movie0_ ) where rownum <= ?

listitem.para: DB scans table as a part of getting data to resolve select clause
No added cost for where or order-by clauses

figure.title: Benchmark
figure.programlisting: FullTableScanIndex.unrestrictedScan: [measured 1 out of 1 rounds, threads: 1 (sequential)] round: 0.91 [+- 0.00], round.block: 0.00 [+- 0.00], round.gc: 0.00 [+- 0.00], GC.calls: 0, GC.time: 0.00, time.total: 0.91, time.warmup: 0.01, time.bench: 0.90

tip.title: No need for an Index for Unconstrained Access to a Table
tip.para: Since the DB's job in this case is to obtain data from all rows of the table in any order -- an index would not add value.

section.title: Full Table Scan: Using Where (without Index)
section.para: Request N rows of data matching a condition on an un-indexed column

figure.title: JPA Query
figure.programlisting: "select m from Movie m where m.rating = :rating", params={rating=R}, limit=1000

figure.title: Generated SQL
figure.programlisting: select * from ( select movie0_.ID as ID1_2_, movie0_.DIRECTOR_ID as DIRECTOR7_2_, movie0_.MINUTES as MINUTES2_2_, movie0_.PLOT as PLOT3_2_, movie0_.RATING as RATING4_2_, movie0_.RELEASE_DATE as RELEASE5_2_, movie0_.TITLE as TITLE6_2_ from JPATUNE_MOVIE movie0_ where movie0_.RATING=? ) where rownum <= ?

listitem.para: Where constraint adds cost to unconstrained query
DB must scan the rows in the table for a match to query

figure.title: Benchmark
figure.programlisting: FullTableScanNoIndex.valueAccess: [measured 1 out of 1 rounds, threads: 1 (sequential)] round: 2.82 [+- 0.00], round.block: 0.00 [+- 0.00], round.gc: 0.00 [+- 0.00], GC.calls: 0, GC.time: 0.00, time.total: 2.82, time.warmup: 0.00, time.bench: 2.82

tip.title: Where Clauses without a Matching Index results in a Full Table Scan
tip.para: Full table scans are the most inefficient way to obtain certain rows from a large DB table.

section.title: RowId Scan: Using Where (with Index)
section.para: Request N rows of data matching a condition on an indexed column

figure.title: DB Index(es)
figure.programlisting: create index movie_rating_idx on jpatune_movie(rating)

figure.title: JPA Query
figure.programlisting: "select m from Movie m where m.rating = :rating", params={rating=R}, limit=1000

figure.title: Generated SQL
figure.programlisting: select * from ( select movie0_.ID as ID1_2_, movie0_.DIRECTOR_ID as DIRECTOR7_2_, movie0_.MINUTES as MINUTES2_2_, movie0_.PLOT as PLOT3_2_, movie0_.RATING as RATING4_2_, movie0_.RELEASE_DATE as RELEASE5_2_, movie0_.TITLE as TITLE6_2_ from JPATUNE_MOVIE movie0_ where movie0_.RATING=? ) where rownum <= ?

listitem.para: Index on where clause search term avoids scanning table -- index scanned instead
DB row is accessed to satisfy select clause
DB row is located by rowId from index

tip.title: Match Indexes for Where Clauses Selecting Small Row Subset from Table
tip.para: An index will speed access to rows within a table when selecting a small subset of a larger table.

section.title: Full Table Scan: Invalidating Index using Function applied to Row Column
section.para: Request N rows of data matching a condition on an indexed column invalidated by a function

figure.title: DB Index(es)
figure.programlisting: create index movie_rating_idx on jpatune_movie(rating)

figure.title: JPA Query
figure.programlisting: "select m from Movie m where upper(m.rating) = :rating", params={rating=R}, limit=1000

figure.title: Generated SQL
figure.programlisting: select * from ( select movie0_.ID as ID1_2_, movie0_.DIRECTOR_ID as DIRECTOR7_2_, movie0_.MINUTES as MINUTES2_2_, movie0_.PLOT as PLOT3_2_, movie0_.RATING as RATING4_2_, movie0_.RELEASE_DATE as RELEASE5_2_, movie0_.TITLE as TITLE6_2_ from JPATUNE_MOVIE movie0_ where upper(movie0_.RATING)=? ) where rownum <= ?

listitem.para: Applying function to column indexed by value invalidates use of index
DB reverts to full table scan to locate row

tip.title: Avoid using Functions on DB Rows within Where Clause
tip.para: Calling a function on a DB column within the where clause will invalidate the use of an index on that column -- unless it is a function-based index (matching what is being used in the where)

section.title: RowId Scan: Using Index with Function applied to Row Column
section.para: Request N rows of data matching a functional condition on a function-indexed column

figure.title: DB Index(es)
figure.programlisting: create index movie_rating_lower_idx on jpatune_movie(lower(rating))

figure.title: JPA Query
figure.programlisting: "select m from Movie m where lower(m.rating) = :rating", params={rating=r}, limit=1000

figure.title: Generated SQL
figure.programlisting: select * from ( select movie0_.ID as ID1_2_, movie0_.DIRECTOR_ID as DIRECTOR7_2_, movie0_.MINUTES as MINUTES2_2_, movie0_.PLOT as PLOT3_2_, movie0_.RATING as RATING4_2_, movie0_.RELEASE_DATE as RELEASE5_2_, movie0_.TITLE as TITLE6_2_ from JPATUNE_MOVIE movie0_ where lower(movie0_.RATING)=? ) where rownum <= ?

listitem.para: Where clause satisfied by scanning function index
DB row accessed to satisfy select clause
DB row accessed by RowId
COST is same order of magnitude (but )as non-function index

tip.title: Define Function Index where Calling Functions on DB rows cannot be Avoided
tip.para: The DB will store the pre-calculated value in the index for use during the query.

section.title: Full Table Scan: Invalidating Index by using Leading Wildcards
section.para: Request N rows of data matching a like condition containing a leading wildcard

figure.title: DB Index(es)
figure.programlisting: create index movie_title_idx on jpatune_movie(title)

figure.title: JPA Query
figure.programlisting: "select m from Movie m where m.title like :title", params={title=%eventeen: The Faces for Fall}, limit=1000

figure.title: Generated SQL
figure.programlisting: select * from ( select movie0_.ID as ID1_2_, movie0_.DIRECTOR_ID as DIRECTOR7_2_, movie0_.MINUTES as MINUTES2_2_, movie0_.PLOT as PLOT3_2_, movie0_.RATING as RATING4_2_, movie0_.RELEASE_DATE as RELEASE5_2_, movie0_.TITLE as TITLE6_2_ from JPATUNE_MOVIE movie0_ where movie0_.TITLE like ? ) where rownum <= ?

listitem.para: Row located using full table scan
Leading wildcard in like invalidates use of indexed column

tip.title: Avoid Leading Wildcards when using Like
tip.para: Leading wildcards invalidate the use of column indexes. Non-leading wildcards continue to indexes.

section.title: Order By using Sort
section.para: Request N rows of data ordered by (ASC) a column

figure.title: DB Index(es)
figure.programlisting: create index movie_title_idx on jpatune_movie(title)

figure.title: JPA Query
figure.programlisting: "select m from Movie m order by title ASC", limit=1000

figure.title: Generated SQL
figure.programlisting: select * from ( select movie0_.ID as ID1_2_, movie0_.DIRECTOR_ID as DIRECTOR7_2_, movie0_.MINUTES as MINUTES2_2_, movie0_.PLOT as PLOT3_2_, movie0_.RATING as RATING4_2_, movie0_.RELEASE_DATE as RELEASE5_2_, movie0_.TITLE as TITLE6_2_ from JPATUNE_MOVIE movie0_ order by movie0_.TITLE ASC ) where rownum <= ?

listitem.para: DB table is scanned as before when unconstrained by where clause
Output is sorted at a noticeable cost increase

tip.title: Sorting adds Cost
tip.para: Look to reduce the number of rows required to be sorted or to use an index (see next topic).

section.title: Order By using Index
section.para: Request N rows of data ordered by (ASC) indexed column (ASC) from where

figure.title: DB Index(es)
figure.programlisting: create index movie_title_idx on jpatune_movie(title)

figure.title: JPA Query
figure.programlisting: "select m from Movie m where m.title like :title order by title ASC", params={title=A%}, limit=1000

figure.title: Generated SQL
figure.programlisting: select * from ( select movie0_.ID as ID1_2_, movie0_.DIRECTOR_ID as DIRECTOR7_2_, movie0_.MINUTES as MINUTES2_2_, movie0_.PLOT as PLOT3_2_, movie0_.RATING as RATING4_2_, movie0_.RELEASE_DATE as RELEASE5_2_, movie0_.TITLE as TITLE6_2_ from JPATUNE_MOVIE movie0_ where movie0_.TITLE like ? order by movie0_.TITLE ASC ) where rownum <= ?

listitem.para: Range scan of index is used to satisfy where clause
Order of index used to satisfy order by clause
Cost significantly less that sort

tip.title: Index-based Sorts are more Efficient
tip.para: It is more efficient to sort results by the indexed values in the where clause because the index is already maintained in sort order.

listitem.para: Oracle implements DESC index as a function index

Function indexes are not handled as efficiently as normal indexes "...cardinality estimates are not as accurate and the SYS_OP_DESCEND and SYS_OP_UNDESCEND functions are used as access/filter conditions as theyâ€™re the functions implemented in the function-based index"

tip.title: Choose Ascending Indexes (over Descending) for Single Columns
tip.para: Ascending indexes can be efficiently traversed in ascending and descending order.
